articles.headline: Chip Makers Watch Sales Fall Sharply
articles.snippet: Global semiconductor sales fell about 29 percent in January amid slumping demand for an array of products that use the chips.
articles.abstract: Global semiconductor sales fell about 29 percent in January amid slumping demand for an array of products that use the chips.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  While accustomed to the boom-and-bust nature of their industry, the companies making the semiconductor chips that run computers, cellphones, digital cameras and even cars find themselves in the middle of a collapse in sales that resembles total chaos.

articles.headline: Afghan Women Slowly Gaining Protection
articles.snippet: A new Constitution and the work of a community of women’s advocates are creating a more egalitarian notion of women’s rights in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: A new Constitution and the work of a community of women’s advocates are creating a more egalitarian notion of women’s rights in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Mariam was 11 in 2003 when her parents forced her to marry a blind, 41-year-old cleric. The bride price of $1,200 helped Mariam’s father, a drug addict, pay off a debt.

articles.headline: U.S. Likely to Keep the Reins on Fannie and Freddie
articles.snippet: The possibility that the mortgage giants could remain in government hands is shaping the debate over the financial industry’s future.
articles.abstract: The possibility that the mortgage giants could remain in government hands is shaping the debate over the financial industry’s future.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite assurances that the takeover of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac would be temporary, the giant mortgage companies will most likely never fully return to private hands, lawmakers and company executives are beginning to quietly acknowledge.

articles.headline: Harvard Medical School in Ethics Quandary
articles.snippet: More than 200 Harvard Medical School students and sympathetic faculty are intent on exposing and curtailing the industry influence in their classrooms and laboratories.
articles.abstract: More than 200 Harvard Medical School students and sympathetic faculty are intent on exposing and curtailing the industry influence in their classrooms and laboratories.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON  In a first-year pharmacology class at Harvard Medical School, Matt Zerden grew wary as the professor promoted the benefits of cholesterol drugs and seemed to belittle a student who asked about side effects.

articles.headline: A Remake of A.I.G. Is the Goal of Rescue
articles.snippet: By easing terms of the $150 billion rescue package, the government is trying to buy time for American International Group to slim down and reinvent itself as a simple property and casualty insurer.
articles.abstract: By easing terms of the $150 billion rescue package, the government is trying to buy time for American International Group to slim down and reinvent itself as a simple property and casualty insurer.
articles.lead_paragraph: By easing the terms of its $150 billion rescue package for the American International Group, the government is trying to buy time for the financial conglomerate to slim down and reinvent itself as a simple property and casualty insurer, with a new name, new faces in the boardroom and perhaps an initial public offering in its future.

articles.headline: The Review Site Yelp Draws Some Outcries of Its Own
articles.snippet: The popular site is struggling to serve competing needs of reviewed businesses, some of whom advertise, and the users, who can anonymously say anything.
articles.abstract: The popular site is struggling to serve competing needs of reviewed businesses, some of whom advertise, and the users, who can anonymously say anything.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  For computer and cellphone users in big American cities, Yelp has become a popular Web site for ranting, raving or just reading about local businesses, from the auto mechanic to the neighborhood watering hole.

articles.headline: The Case for Saving A.I.G., by A.I.G.
articles.snippet: A confidential document from the insurance giant warns of a “systemic risk” should the company crumble.
articles.abstract: A confidential document from the insurance giant warns of a “systemic risk” should the company crumble.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inside the corridors of power in Washington, a 21-page document has been getting a lot of attention. It is marked confidential and titled “A.I.G.: Is the Risk Systemic?”

articles.headline: Memos Reveal Scope of Power Bush Sought in Fighting Terror
articles.snippet: The secret legal opinions were issued by Bush administration lawyers after the Sept. 11 attacks.
articles.abstract: The secret legal opinions were issued by Bush administration lawyers after the Sept. 11 attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The secret legal opinions issued by Bush administration lawyers after the Sept. 11 attacks included assertions that the president could use the nation’s military within the United States to combat terrorism suspects and to conduct raids without obtaining search warrants.

articles.headline: Clinton Says U.S. Is Ready to Begin Talks With Syria
articles.snippet: An understanding with Syria could increase pressure on Iran to respond to the United States’ offer of direct talks.
articles.abstract: An understanding with Syria could increase pressure on Iran to respond to the United States’ offer of direct talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  Signaling a new direction in Middle East diplomacy, the Obama administration will send two senior officials to Syria this weekend to begin discussions with the government, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said on a visit to Israel on Tuesday.
